title: Small YouTubers
body:
In light of the current circumstances, I’d like to take the time to appreciate some YouTubers I watch that are a bit on the smaller side (under 1 million subscribers is my goal.) Hopefully it can shed some light on some interesting people who deserve recognition, and do what YouTube isn’t. (Channel links on their names)

Julia Zelg

Recently, Julia hit 100k subscribers and got her first play button! She is a pastel goth and mostly makes fashion videos, along with story times and advice videos, but recently has been doing a lot of videos with her fiancé Eileen. She is from Brazil so if you have hearing troubles I would recommend subtitles on her videos as her accent is fairly heavy. Easy to understand if you don’t have audio issues, but if you do, just slap on those captions.

A Clockwork Reader

Hannah is a booktuber, mostly centering around book reviews, hauls, lists, and a few games here and then. Her voice is very soothing and her commentary is incredibly intelligent. However, if you’re not that big into books or YouTube about books, probably avoid her channel.

CrankGameplays

Listen, if you watch Jacksepticeye or Markiplier, you probably know who this guy is. On the off chance you do watch those two but don’t know who he is, or have no idea who I’m talking about in general, this man’s name is Ethan. As it says in his channel name, he plays games! If you want some darker humor, with some very light-hearted edges, you’ll love Ethan. I absolutely think he deserves just as much recognition as the other big gamers. Most of his videos are under twenty minutes, so you can easily watch a few of them in a row.

Jessica Kellgren-Fozard

A YouTuber I only just started watching, but one I would highly recommend! Jessica’s videos mainly consist of vintage fashion (particularly 1940s and 1950s), queer culture (she and her wife are adorable), and her disabilities (she is deaf and has some sort of connective tissue disorder, but I can’t remember what). Her speaking voice is very pleasant to the ear if you are abled hearing, but if you aren’t, she obviously has plenty of subtitles. 

Finally, pixlpit (or betapixl)

Again, if you watch Jack’s videos, you most likely know him, but again, I believe he deserves way more recognition for his own content as well. An animator and gamer, though not as active on his animation channel (pixlpit), he has a very deadpan sense of humor I find endlessly entertaining, and a fantastic editing style (honestly, as an aspiring editor, I look up to him a lot).

That’s most of the smaller YouTubers I watch, if you have any others you’d like to recommend (particularly queer or POC), I absolutely want to hear about them, and I’d love to start a trend of boosting smaller content creators with a lot to say. I hope, if any of these strike your fancy, you check them out and give them a bit of love they deserve!

tags: nobody deserves to have their money stolen to pay someone else's debts or failures
title: The $1.7 Million Lie
excerpt: The Defy saga continues...A few weeks ago, I told you my personal history with MCNs and how this industry, one that was built to revolutionize entertainment,...
description:
Recap: Creators often sign with MCNs (Multi-channel Networks that protect them from copyright issues with fair use of music/images). Defy was one such MCN. Youtube, instead of sending their content creators a paycheck directly, has been sending it to Defy’s bank accounts. Defy was then supposed to subtract their usage fee and send the rest on to the creators. 
.
Defy used this to make their bank accounts look good even though none of it was their money, and convinced their bank, Ally Bank, to give them a loan. Then Defy shut down. Ally Bank is now holding the content creator’s paychecks Defy has held in their account. They plan to use that money to pay off Defy’s business debts even though, again, none of it was ever Defy’s money.

Ally Bank currently plans to steal the paychecks of Youtube Creators to cover their own failure to deep dive into Defy before loaning them money.
